The teacher has a 3-year old small business selling prepared foods and with this first loan request she will use the money to purchase firewood and various products to be used in food preparation. She sells enchiladas, refreshments, sliced beef, chicken, pork and cheese, in the afternoon from 2PM until 10 PM. Her husband is a refrigerator technician, with his own workshop, which he operates out of their home.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy material for food preparation

loans.name: Alonso

texts.es: Alonso T. de 29 años de edad, es soltero, trabajador del Hospital Asunción, con 2 años de servicio, habita en casa de su mamá donde hará la mejora de la vivienda que consiste en instalar una extractor de humo para evitar que el humo de la cocina entre en la vivienda, además legalizará un terreno de su propiedad ya que piensa prepararse para el futuro, donde con esfuerzo propio y con la ayuda de los créditos piensa construir su propia vivienda. Está solicitando su segundo crédito el que está dispuesto a cancelar en tiempo y forma, ya que se considera un joven responsable, honesto y cumplidor de los acuerdos que asume. Su sueño es poder terminar de acondicionar la casa de su mamá antes de empezar la propia.
texts.en:
Alonso T. is 29 years old, and a bachelor who has worked at Asunción hospital for two years. He lives at home with his mother, and he would like to make improvements to the house by installing a fan to prevent kitchen smoke from entering the rest of the house. Additionally, he will formalize ownership of some land on which, through his own endeavors and with some loan assistance, he is planning to build his own home in the future. The loan he is currently requesting would be his second. He intends to repay it in full and on time as he considers himself a responsible and honest young man, who fulfills the agreements he makes. His dream is to finish remodeling his mother’s home prior to beginning his own.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installation of a kitchen smoke ventilator

loans.name: Lupe

texts.en: Lupe T., 28, is married with 4 children. She has many years of experience in a plantation business. She and her husband do the planting. She sells to the village and general public 3 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 550 Tala (approximately 229 USD). SPBD loans are Lupe's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for home improvement.

loans.use: To buy Gromozone, bush knives and pesticides, and also to purchase cement for home improvement.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
María García D. L. C. is a member of community bank, Urubamba, which has a community group that meets every two weeks. Maria lives about 20 minutes outsiD. of urban Ayacucho. With the help of her cousin and nephew, Maria runs a glass store, and they have been working together at the store for 10 years. 

With the loan of 3,000 soles, Maria will be able to invest into her business by purchasing glass, scaffolding and putty and she will also be able to pay rent. With the income and savings she receives from her business she dreams of ensuring her daughter receives an education and works professionally; additionally, she would like to build her own home.

loans.use: Purchase glass, scaffolding and putty, and pay rent.

loans.name: Martha Lidia

texts.es: La Sra. Marta Lidia, soltera, con 2 hijos de 11 y 6 años ambos estudian la educación primaria, el horario de trabajo que tiene es de 8:00 am a 4:00 pm de lunes a viernes, con 19 años de servicio, está solicitando su 4to. Crédito el que tiene destinado para empezar la construcción de su vivienda, construirá ocho metros cuadrados de arranques donde la Alcaldia de Juigalpa con el INVUR le construirá su vivienda ya que actualmente habita en una casa que paga el MINSA donde funciona FETSALUD, en la que no tiene condiciones, ni privacidad, pues sus hijos están creciendo y quiere darles un techo aunque sea módico, con la esperanza de ir mejorándolo posteriormente ya que siente que tiene las puertas abiertas en AFODENIC porque sus créditos los ha cancelado en tiempo y forma, es una persona muy responsable y con alto sentido de honradez y moral de pago.
texts.en:
Ms. Marta Lidia is single with two boys ages 11 and 6-years old. Both are studying in elementary school while she works from 8 AM to 4 PM Monday through Friday. With 19-years of service as a health worker, she requests a loan to start on the construction of her house. She would like to build an 8-square metered house in Alcaldia de Juigalpa with the INVUR (Institute of Urban and Rural Housing). Where Ms. Lidia currently resides she must pay MINSA (Ministry of Health) which operates FETASALUD (Federation of Health Workers) and the conditions there provide no privacy for her growing children. She would like to put a modest roof over their heads, with the hope that things will get better. She feels that doors have opened with AFODENIC and will pay her loan back in a timely manner as she is a very responsible person with a high sense of honor to do what is morally correct to pay her debt.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To start construction on her house

loans.name: Eladia

texts.es: La señora Eladia está solicitando refinanciamiento de su crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (cambiarle el zinc a la casa), trabaja como docente del Nerpe El Triunfo,  desde hace 8 años, tiene dos hijas, la mayor de 17 años  estudia su quinto año de Educación secundaria y la niña menor de 12 años estudia su sexto grado de educación primaria, su esposo trabaja en la quesera el Triunfo, y ambos comparten los gastos del hogar, la profesora Eladia es una mujer trabajadora, responsable, honesta, vive en comarca el Triunfo,   actualmente  esta estudiando quinto año  en la Univesidad  URACCAN Recinto Nueva Guinea, sueña con que a sus hijas no les falte nada para que en el futuro sean mujeres de bien y contar con estabilidad laboral para así ayudar a su familia pues son familias pobres pero muy trabajadoras y muy queridas por la comunidad.La Sra. S.  se siente agradecida con AFODENIC ya que con los creditos brindados por  la institución ha logrado comprar electrodomésticos y ha mejorado la infraestructura de su casa.
texts.en:
Mrs. Eladia seeks refinancing to invest in home improvements (replacing the zinc in the house). She works as a teacher at the Nerpe El Tirunfo, where she has taught for 8 years. She has two children: the oldest daughter is 17-years old and is studying in the 5th year of secondary school and the younger daughter is 12-years old and is studying in the 6th grade. Her husband works at the Cheese Factory of Triunfo and they both share in the household expenses. Mrs. Eladia is a hard working woman, who is responsible and honest. She lives in Comarca el Tirunfo, and is currently in her fifth year at the University of URACCAN in New Guinea. She dreams for her children to not miss out on anything and that they have the best future. She also wants for them to have stable jobs and in turn for them to help families who are needy, but hardworking and mindful of the community. Mrs. S. is grateful to AFODENIC, because with the loan offered by the institution she has been able to purchase appliances and has improved the infrastructure of her house.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To change/replace the zinc in her house

loans.name: Talaave

texts.en: Talaave T., 52, is married with ten children. She has 3 years of experience in the pancakes, porkcakes, ice cakes, etc. business. She sells to the village and general public 3 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are Talaave's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for home improvement and part will be used to purchase bags of flour, sugar, seasoning oil, soy sauce, salt, iron roofing, and timber for home improvement. Talaave's earning from her business will cater for her family needs but mainly is for business improvement.

loans.use: Talaave would like to improve her food business to support her ten children.

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina P. M. is a member of FINCA Perú's community bank, Kuskanchik. She is 28 years old, sells clothes for women, men and children during the week and on the weekends she travels and sings traditional Ayacuchan music.

Saturnina will invest her loan into her business by purchasing CDs for her music, equipment and payments for burning music to the CDs, and bus tickets which she needs to travel to sell clothes, pants, t-shirts and sweaters. With the income she receives from her business, she dreams of having a permanent store to sell clothes in Ayacucho.

loans.use: To purchase CDs for her music, equipment and payments for burning music to the CDs, and bus tickets which she needs to travel to sell clothes, pants, t-shirts and sweaters.

loans.name: Gladis

texts.en:
Gladys Q. D. L. C. is a member of the community bank, Virgén D. Cocharcas at FINCA Perú. Gladys, a widow living in Ayacucho with her three children aged 21, 19 and 4, sells vegetables at a local market to support her family and herself.

The loan that she has requested will cover the purchase of lettuce, tomatoes, eggplant, mushrooms, carrots and cabbage. With the income and savings she gains from her business she hopes to ensure that her children continue their educations and become professionals. She also would love to own her own house and her own store where she could sell her vegetables and perhaps increase her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase lettuce, tomatoes, eggplant, mushrooms, carrots and cabbage.

loans.name: Taliilagi

texts.en: Taliilagi M., 26, is married and has three children.  She has many years of experience in the food market business. She sells to the public five days per week. She has four previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 550 Tala (about $229 USD).  SPBD loans are Taliilagi's only access to capital because she was cannot qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She will use the loan to buy flour, sugar, plastic cups, kool aid, seasonings, oil, and a big frying pan. She will use her earnings to improve her business and to help out with family expenses. Her husband is a taxi driver.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her market

loans.name: Faalevela

texts.en: Faalevela Robert, 59, is married with eight children. She has many years of experience in the shop business. She sells to the village people 6 days per week. She has 6 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (~$291 USD). SPBD loans are Faalevela's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will used her loan to buy goods needed for the shop and also some timber and cement to expand her store. Her husband and the older daughter help her with the business.

loans.use: Faalevela would like to purchase goods for her store and to buy timber and cement to expand her shop.

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es: La Sra. Martha Lorena está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 8vo crédito, con este préstamo pretende repellar la  casa, trabaja como docente de la escuela el Triunfo  desde hace 8 años, tiene 2 hijos, el mayor de 10 años, estudia su quinto grado de educación primaria y la niña menor de 8 años,  a pesar que no tiene la ayuda del padre de sus hijos ha salido adelante con ellos, pues es una mujer que trabaja duro, con dos plazas de docente, ella se caracteriza por ser honesta y muy trabajadora, actualmente está estudiando su tercer año en la Universidad URACCAN, vive en la zona # 8 de Nueva Guinea, recibe la ayuda de su mamá quien le ayuda a cuidar los niños, su sueño es seguir estudiando, tener salud, y que sus hijos estudien   y  no le falte nada y contar con estabilidad laboral
texts.en:
Ms. Martha Lorena is requesting to refinance her loan with the intent to repair her home. For the last 8 years, she has been working as a teacher at the Triunfo School. She has two children with the oldest now 10-years old studying in the 5th grade and the younger son, now 8-years old. Although she has no help from the father of her children as he has left them, she is a hard working woman with two teaching positions. She is characterized to be honest and diligent, and is currently in her third year at the University of URACCAN. She lives in Nueva Guinea’s zone 8, and receives help from her mother who also helps to take care of the children. Ms. Lorenas’ dreams are to continue studying, have good health and that her children get an education, without missing out on anything and that they get stable jobs.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair the walls of her house

loans.name: Ruta

texts.en: Ruta L., 50, is married with 3 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the taxi business. She sells to the public 6 days a week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Ruta's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to buy a door handle for the taxi, car lights, paint and tires to replace the old ones. Her husband is helping her operating the business.

loans.use: Purchasing a door handle, car lights, paint and tires

loans.name: Nubia Mayra

texts.es: La Sra. Nubia está solicitando  su financiamiento  para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (Construcción de una habitación), trabaja como docente en el Nerpe el Triunfo desde hace 10 años, tiene 3 hijos, el mayor de  15 años de edad estudia su tercer año de Educación secundaria la otra  hija  de 11 años estudia su quinto grado de Educación primaria y un niño menor de 8 años;  Nubia se ha destacado por ser responsable, trabajadora  y muy participativa en las actividades de su comunidad, su compañero de vida es comerciante este viaja a las colonias del Municipio de Nueva Guinea a vender y a comprar productos perecederos,  ambos comparten los gastos familiares del hogar ya que son una familia pobre, este prestamo lo piensa pagar en 12 meses y así poco a poco ir mejorando su vivienda, viven en un barrio de comarca el Triunfo donde cada día se va aumentando la población , su sueño es ir mejorando la vivienda con cada crédito que esta va adquiriendo con AFODENIC y se siente feliz de seguir trabajando con la institución,   sueña tener estabilidad laboral, salud y que su hijos sigan estudiando para que lleguen hacer alguien en la vida.
texts.en:
Ms. Nubia Lopez is seeking funding to invest in the improvement of her house (building a room). For the last 10-years, she has been working as a teacher in the Nerpe el Triunfo. She has 3 children: the oldest is 15-years old and is in the 3rd year of secondary school, the other daughter is 11-years old and is in the 5th grade and the youngest is 8-years old. Ms. Nubia is known for being responsible, hardworking and very active in the community. Her companion’s trade is to travel to the colonies of Municipal Nueva Guinea to sell and purchase perishable products. Both Nubia and her companion share in the expenses of their home as they are a poor family. This loan, which they believe will be repaid in 12-months, will gradually help them make improvements to their home. They live in the borough of Comarca el Triunfo, which each day seems to be increasing in population. Her dream is to have a better home with this loan from AFODENIC and she feels happy to continue working with the institution. She dreams of having a stable job, good health and that her children continue to study to be successful in life.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a new room

loans.name: Meipo

texts.en: Meipo I., 27, is married with 4 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the taxi business. She works 5 days a week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Meipo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to fund repairing seats, new parking lights, tires and a front rear window. Her husband is lending his full support to his wife in operating her business.

loans.use: Repairing seats and purchasing new parking lights, tires and a front rear window

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en: Amelia Micheal, 67, is married with 9 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the taxi business. She works 6 days a week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Amelia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to repaint the taxi, to repair the front rear window, and to purchase new tires and car fuel. Her husband helps her in running their business.

loans.use: to repaint the taxi, to repair the front rear window, and to purchase new tires and car fuel

loans.name: Puniala

texts.en:
Puniala F., 38 and married with six children, has several years of experience in the plantation business. Assisted by her husband, she sells to the public five days per week, realizing a weekly net cash flow of about $100.

SPBD loans are Puniala's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for loans from traditional banks. She is requesting a loan in order to buy sacks of fertilizers, bush knives, cromozone and spades.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fertilizers, bush knives, cromozone and spades

loans.name: Vaitoa

texts.en: Vaitoa T., 27, is married with 2 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the taxi business. She sells to the public 6 days a week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Vaitoa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to repair the front rear window of the taxi, and to purchase tires, paint and car fuel. Her husband helps her in operating the business.

loans.use: to repair the front rear window of the taxi, and to purchase tires, paint and car fuel

loans.name: Peleiupu

texts.en: Peleiupu A., 39, is married with 6 children. She has many years of experience in a banana chips business. She sells to school children and the public 5 days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately 166 USD). SPBD loans are Peleiupu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to buy gallons of oil, bunches of bananas, plastic bags and a frying pan to replace the old one. Her daughter helps her to operate the business.

loans.use: To purchase gallons of oil, bunches of bananas, plastic bags and a frying pan

loans.name: Faitele

texts.en:
Faitele A., 26 and married with two children, has one year of experience in the ice cake business, selling to the public six days per week. Her husband helps her with the business. She has received two previous loans with SPBD and expects her weekly net cash flow to soon rise to $125.

SPBD loans are Faitele's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for loans from traditional banks; her current loan request is for the purpose of buying foam cups, Kool Aid, sugar and a second hand refrigerator.

loans.use: To buy foam cups, Kool Aid, sugar and a second hand refrigerator.

loans.name: Pepe

texts.en:
Pepe A., 50, is married with 4 children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village and general public 3 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).

SPBD loans are Pepe's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for home renovation. Pepe's earning will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses. Her husband and children work on the plantation.

loans.use: Buy bushknives, barbed wire, pesticides, gromozone, and timber for home improvement

loans.name: Vaitele

texts.en: Vaitele V., 60, is married and has eight children.  She has three years of experience in the fish business. She sells  fish three days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala ($145 USD). SPBD loans are Vaitele's only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with  traditional banks. Her earnings will be use to improve her business and help out with her family's expenses. Her husband does the fishing with  help from his two boys.

loans.use: Purchase a  canoe, spears, fishing rod, fishing torch, and a big cooler

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy supplies for her business and cement for a home-improvement project

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en: Epifania K., 50, is married with 5 children.  She has 3 year(s) of experience in the pancakes, porkcakes, ice cakes, etc. business. She sells to the village and general public 5 days per week. She has 1 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Epifania's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.part of her loan will buy cement for home improvement.Epifania's earning will be use to improve business and help out with family, husand is a fisherman.

loans.use: Buy bag of flour, sugar, salt, plastic papers, cooking oil, big frying pan, kool aid, and cement for home improvements

loans.name: Yong

texts.en: Yong O., 40, is married and lives with her three children in Phnom Penh. She is a chef in a restaurant, making around US$6 each day. Her husband has a business of raising ducks for eggs, and normally he sells the eggs to the market and can generate about US$4 of income each day. Inflation has driven up prices all across Cambodia and many Cambodians have faced economic struggles. Yong O. has approached CREDIT for a loan to purchase more ducks for her husband to breed. She feels that this will be a sustainable investment that will keep profits high and generate more income for her family. (Husband is pictured with the ducks.)

loans.use: To raise more ducks.

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en: Chhum T., 30, is married and lives in the Phnom Penh with her husband and two young children. Since 2005, she has been working as cattle dealer together with her husband and they typically make $2 each day. Chhum T. would like to get a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $800 to purchase more cows for trade.

loans.use: To purchase more cows for trade.

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en: Chhum M., 40, is a widow and lives with her three children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has been selling many kinds of vegetables, pork, and beef in the village. She is able to make around $2 USD each day and is aided by three of her children who work in garment factories. She also has one niece whom she takes care of. Chhum M. would like a $1000 USD loan to increase the number of items she sells. She said that her husband was the breadwinner of the family, but since he died, she started this business to support her family. Both competition and inflation make it difficult to earn enough to support her family.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Chhang

texts.en: Chhang N., 49, lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and one child. She works with her husband selling porridge and grocery products every day. Their combined income is typically US$6 each day. Many in Cambodia are facing economic difficulties with rising inflation making both food and especially rice prices soar. Her son is married but still lives with her. Chhang has asked CREDIT for a loan of $1000 USD to purchase a motorbike for her son to operate a motor-taxi. This will increase their daily income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her son to operate a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Morm

texts.en:
Morm S., 39, is married and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and five children. She works in a grocery store, making around US$3.30 each day, while her husband typically makes US$2.50 every day as a village teacher. 

Morm would like to receive a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to add to the grocery store's inventory. She said that all of her children are students and she wants all of them to complete a bachelor degree or learn a specific skill in order to easily take care of themselves. She said it is not going to be easy to earn the money to support the children's education, but she will try and hopes that after she diversifies her inventory of products she may earn more than ever. (Her husband is pictured at home.)

loans.use: To buy more groceries.

loans.name: Om

texts.en: Om S., 28, is married and lives in Phnom Penh with her two young children. She sells construction tools in the market, while her husband runs a small store in the market selling groceries, making about US$5 every day. It seems to be hard for every vendor and farmer because the inflation this year is out of control and the weather is unbelievable. Om S. has approached CREDIT for a loan to add to her construction tool inventory. She believes that this will be a sustainable investment which will raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To add to her construction tool inventory.

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Ven C., 47, is a housewife who lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She works hard to prepare the food for the family members, while her husband is a construction foreman, making around US$5 each day. This couple has two children, one of whom is a car mechanic earning about US$3 per day. Ven C. would like to take out a loan to breed cows for sale, and also to repair her house.

loans.use: To breed cows.

loans.name: Pendora

texts.en: Pendora L., 51, is married with 7 children. She has 2 years of experience in a taxi business. She operates to the public 5 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately 166 USD). SPBD loans are Pendora's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy four windows and car paint for the taxi, and the money left will be used to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase four car windows and car paint and to pay for her kids' school fees.

loans.name: Leipu

texts.en: Leipu P., 35, is married with 6 children. She has 3 years of business experience in a shop. She sells to village people and public 5 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately 166 USD). SPBD loans are Leipu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy goods for the shop and a new refrigerator. Her oldest son is helping her with the business.

loans.use: To purchase goods for the shop and a refrigerator

loans.name: Nerisa

texts.en:
Nerisa T., 38, is married with four children. She has three years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public four days per week. 

She has had four previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~$125 USD).

SPBD loans are Nerisa's only access to capital, because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to buy knives, weed killer and pesticides for the betterment of her plantation business. Her husband is helping her with the business.

loans.use: Purchase to buy knives,weedkiller and pesticides.

loans.name: Soo

texts.en: Soo L., 41, is married with 2 children.  She has 5 years of experience running a store. She sells to the public 6 days a week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Soo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy goods for the shop and to purchase things for home improvement like cement, timber and nails. Her husband is helping her with the business.

loans.use: Purchasing goods for the shop and for home improvement

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long S., 35, is married and lives with her husband and four of her children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Since 2002, she has been selling many kinds of vegetables in the village to earn a living, and is able to make about US$1.50 each day, while her husband is employed in construction, making US$5 per day. Two of their children are students and one is a garment factory worker with a daily income US$2.50 per day. Long said she spends around US$75 each month on expenses and US$15 on her children's education. To double the family's income, Mrs. Long would like to take out a loan to breed cows. In the future, she plans to set up another business of selling groceries.

loans.use: To breed cows.

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese F., 54, is married and has seven children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells her produce in the village three days per week. She has three previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (about $208 USD). SPBD loans are Akenese's only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase items for her plantation (chemicals, bush knives, weed killer, axe, and so forth) and to pay for her children's school fees. Her husband helps her with the business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for the plantation and to pay school fees

loans.name: Losivale

texts.en: Losivale L., 78, is widowed with seven children. She has many years of experience in the Plantation/Vegetable Garden business. She sells to the village and public 4 days per week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Losivale's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to buy gromozones, knives, vegetable seeds, rakes and cucumber. Her husband died and she is working on her business together with the help of her children.

loans.use: Losivale would like to purchase vegetables and supplies for her vegetable business.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann S., 30, is married and lives in Phnom Penh with her little child. She is a rice farmer, making around US$3, while her husband has a business as a motor-taxi driver, typically making US$4 each day. She said she wants her son to complete high school and then acquire a specific skill to raise a family. Ann S. has asked CREDIT [Kiva’s Field Partner] for a loan of US$1000 to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband. The old motorbike uses a lot of gas when it is operating. In the future, if she has enough capital she will set up a grocery store to make extra profit.

loans.use: To replace her husband's motorbike for his motor-taxi business

loans.name: Valasiolaga

texts.en: Valasiologa B., 34, is single with no children.  She has many years of experience in the store business. She sells to the public 7 days a week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).  SPBD loans are Valasiologo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to buy a box of mutton flaps, chicken legs, sausages, pots, teapots, a new oven and other materials used in her business. Her older sister is helping her run the business.

loans.use: purchasing a box of mutton flaps, chicken legs, sausages, pots, teapots, a new oven and other materials used in her business

loans.name: Tasi

texts.en: Tasi S., 50, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days a week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Tasi's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase chemicals, pesticides, bush knives, spades and an axe. Her whole family, including her husband, supports this business.

loans.use: purchasing chemicals, pesticides, bush knives, spades and an axe

loans.name: Paugata

texts.en: Paugata L., 19, is single with no children. She has many years of experience in a handicrafts business. She sells to the village people and general puplic 6 days per week. She has had two previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD). SPBD loans are Paugata's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase carving materials such as a rip saw chain and paints to decorate the crafts and designs. Her mother is lending a helping hand to her business.

loans.use: To purchase carving materials such as a rip saw chain and paints to decorate the crafts and designs

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao S., 45, is married and lives with three of her children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She works as a farmer, making about US$3, while her husband typically makes US$3 every day from raising pigs for sale. They are also supported by one of their children who works in the garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation is out of control and has forced food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. In light of these times of economic difficulties, Sao S. is asking CREDIT for a loan to breed pigs and to buy food for them as well. She sees this loan as a way to increase her income and is confident that the business venture will be successful. (Her husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To raise pigs.

loans.name: Luavalu

texts.en: Luavalu G., 50, is married with 8 children. She has many years of experience in a taro and banana plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public 3 days per week. She has had 5 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (approximately 145 USD). SPBD loans are Luavalu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase taro tubers, weed killer, pesticides, chemicals and a shovel. Her husband helps her with the business.

loans.use: To purchase taro tubers, weed killer, pesticides, chemicals and a shovel

loans.name: Chhen

texts.en: Chhen O., 61, is married and lives with her husband and three of her children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has been growing rice to earn a living and is able to make about $4 USD each day. Her husband, Meas BO., 60, is the village teacher and normally he makes $3 USD per day. All the children are employed, one sells groceries and two are teachers like their father. Chhen would like to take out a loan of $1000 USD to increase the inventory in her child's grocery store.

loans.use: To buy items for the grocery ctore

loans.name: Toefuataina

texts.en: Toefuataina C., 32, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to the village people and general puplic 3 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).  SPBD loans are Toefuataina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to buy taro tubers, weed killer, pesticides, chemicals and a shovel. Her whole family supports this business.

loans.use: Purchasing taro tubers, weed killer, pesticides, chemicals and a shovel

loans.name: Meay

texts.en: Meay Y., 47, sells small vegetables at a local market in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is married with two children, who are still living at home. Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver. She typically earns around US$6 each day. She is requesting a loan of US$700 to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband. The old one uses a lot of gas and needs to be fixed often which costs a lot of money.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Serafina

texts.en: Serafina F., 49, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and banana plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers 2 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD).  SPBD loans are Serafina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to buy a spade, a crowbar, weed killer and chemicals. Her husband is helping her with the business.

loans.use: buying a spade, a crowbar, weed killer and chemicals

loans.name: Vaipouli

texts.en: Vaipouli S., 55, is married with 12 children.  She has many years of experience with banana plantation and vegetable garden businesses. She sells to the villagers 2 days per week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 550 Tala (~229 USD).  SPBD loans are Vaipouli's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  A very lucky mother of twelve, all her children are now employed, which is why she's requesting a smaller loan than her entitlement. She will only use her loan to buy weed killer, gromozone, sting, vegetable seeds and a sack of fertilizer. Her husband is helping her with the business.

loans.use: Purchase weedkiller gromozone, sting, vegetable seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Yun

texts.en: Yun V., 50, is a widow who lives with four of her children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She has been selling fish to earn a living since 2000 and is able to make about US$2 each day. Three of her children are employed in garment factories. She requests a loan of US$500 to increase the number of fish to sell. Any remaining money will be used to purchase land for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Siaumua

texts.en:
Siaumau O., 54, is married with 12 children. She has many years of experience in the banana plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers 2 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).

SPBD loans are Siaumau's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She aims to expand her plantation, but she needs the support from her family. For improvement of her plantation business, she will use the loan to buy weed killer, fertilizer, and fungicide for bananas. She is looking forward to starting up another business when her plantation business is successful.

loans.use: Purchase weedkiller chemicals and fungicides and a backpack spayer

loans.name: Sitoga

texts.en: Sitoga L., 36, is married with 2 children.  She has many yea(s of experience in the taro and banana plantation business. She sells to the general public and the villagers 2 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Sitoga's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to purchase wire for a fence, a sack of fertilizer, and pesticides.

loans.use: Purchase wire for a fence, a sack of fertilizer, and pesticides

loans.name: Molealii

texts.en: Molealii A., 49, is married with five children. She has many years of experience in a plantation and cattle farming business. She sells to the general public and villagers two days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD). SPBD loans are Molealii's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Molealii runs two businesses and mainly works on the taro plantation, while her husband works in the farm. Her main aim is that one day, she can be independent without borrowing anymore.

loans.use: To purchase weedkiller chemicals such as Gromozone, Sting and Roundup, fertilizers and fencing for cattle.

loans.name: Leas

texts.en:
Leas S., 61, is married and lives with six of her children in the Siem Reap province. She works with her husband farming land and typically makes US$5 each day. Both of them started farming in 1980 and they state that output has come down in recent years due to drought conditions. Another issue that they are affected by is the doubling of the cost of fertilizer.

Most of the farmers grow rice two times per year; once, in the dry season which takes bout 3-4 months and once in the rainy season which takes about 6-7 months. Wealthy people prefer rice planted in the rainy season. Leas S. would requests a loan of US$1000 to purchase a hand tractor to plow their farmland. In the future, they would like to raise animals to earn more money.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor.

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Vannak's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao V. is a village bank president of twenty-one members in Stueng Village in Kandal Province. The members will use the loan in various ways. For instance, Mrs. Mao V. owns a pool table which she rents to players. Her husband, Mr. Huot Savan, helps her in the business. They have nine children; seven of whom are employed in different businesses while the remaining two are attending the local school. Although Mrs. Mao V.'s family members have different business activities, they still do not have enough money to complete their house. Thus, Mrs. Mao V. has decided to request a loan to add to her savings to build a staircase for her house.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a staircase for her house.

loans.name: Ihana

texts.en: Ihana A., 51, is married and has five children.  She has many years of experience growing vegetables. She sells fruits and vegetables four days per week. She has two previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 440 Tala (about $183 USD).  SPBD loans are Ihana's only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She will use part of her loan to pay her son's school fees. Ihana has been selling pancakes for the past two years, but due to the cost of living in Samoa, she realized that her pancake business was not making much, so she is now concentrating on her vegetable garden.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, vegetable seeds, gardening tools, a wheelbarrow, gloves.

loans.name: Chhon

texts.en: Chhon S., 26, is married and lives with her husband and three children in the Siem Reap province. Since 2004, she has been selling many kinds of vegetables to earn a living and is able to make about $3 USD each day. Her husband, Lon Chan, 26, typically makes about $5 USD from a motor-taxi business. Chhon S. would like to take out a loan of $1000 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to run his business. In the future, if she has enough money, she will purchase a store in the market where she will be able to attract more customers.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Vaioleti

texts.en: Vaioleti A., 38, is married with four children.  She has many years of experience in the retail business. She sells to other villagers three days per week. She has had four previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 850 Tala (~354 USD).  SPBD loans are Vaioleti's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Vaioleti's small shop is open 7 days a week from 6am to 10pm. She's a very hard-working lady aiming to be successful. She will use the loan to purchase milk, mosquito coils, diapers, soaps, onions, salt sugar flour, rice, tin meats, lamp flaps, chicken, sausages, and ham.

loans.use: Purchase items for her shop.

loans.name: Norm

texts.en: Norm T., 26, is married and lives with one child. She works making baskets in the Siem Reap province and typically makes US$1.50 each day. She is also supported by her husband who works as a sculptor and makes a profit of US$3 each day. Norm T. is requesting a loan of US$400 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This will help reduce the daily expense that her husband spends every day on a motor-taxi driver.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en: Epenesa M., 54, is married and has six children. She has many years of experience in her shop business, which is open six days per week. She has five previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1500 Tala (about $625 USD). SPBD loans are Epenesa's only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Epenesa has a very good loan history, she always pays in advance, and she saves every week.

loans.use: Purchase a refrigerator and display shelves

loans.name: Mrs. Mot Sreang's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of twenty members, is located in Trapeang Krasang Village in Kampong the Cham Province. Mrs. Mot S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Mrs. Mot S. is 42 years old and is the mother of two children one of whom works in a garment factoR. while the youngest attends the local school. She owns a lake where she raises fish for a living. Mrs. Mot S.'s fish have maN. babies but she does not have enough money to buy more food for them. Thus, she has decided to make a request for a loan so that she can purchase more fish food. Her husband, Mr. Ly Vannchroy, is a construction worker and a cow breeder.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Nine members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more food to feed her fish.

loans.name: Mai

texts.en: Mai S., 42, is married and often works with his wife in the Siem Reap province selling vegetables and fish in the market. Since 2006, his wife, Pot Sila (pictured), 30, has been selling vegetables and fish to earn approximately US$20 in revenue everyday. The couple have four children together. Mr. Mai S. requests a loan of US$500 to begin breeding pigs for sale.

loans.use: To breed pigs for sale.

loans.name: Itagia

texts.en: Itagia A., 45, is married with 3 children.  She has many years of experience in a barbecue business. She sells to the general public and villagers 5 days per week.  She has had three previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD).  SPBD loans are Itagia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Itagia sells barbecued food near the road side, next to the international airport.  Her main clients are passing traffic and workers at the airport.

loans.use: To purchase a bigger BBQ stove, a box of lamb flaps, chicken, sausages, tomato sauce, onions, garlic and charcoal.

loans.name: Mrs. Seum Sorn's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty people in Toul Vihea Village in Kampong Cham Province make up this village bank loan which will be used for different purposes. Mrs. Seum S. is a village bank president that has a plantation where she cultivates rice. She does not have enough money to buy more rice to plant so she has decided to ask for a loan to purchase rice seed. Her husband, Mr. E. Vong, helps with the rice plantation. Mrs. Seum S. is 56 years old and the mother of a 16 year old child who is still attending school. 

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Ten members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase rice seed to cultivate on her plantation.

loans.name: Prom

texts.en: Prom P., 44, is a widow living in the Kampong Cham province with one of her two children. She sells vegetables and fermented fish in the market to earn approximately US$7.50 each day. Prom P. is requesting a loan of US$1000 to increase the amount of vegetables and fermented fish for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables and fermented fish for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Vin Khum's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which is located in Svay Pok Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, consists of nine people. Mrs.Vin K. is the village bank president as selected by the members. She and her husband, Mr. Norn Kron, are farmers who cultivate rice to earn a living. The plantation has recently become infertile producing smaller yields so Mrs Vin K. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to increase crop production. Mrs. Vin K. is 36 years old and the mother of four children who are all attending the local school. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to increase crop yields.

loans.name: Muliolo

texts.en:
Muliolo T., 44, is married with two children. She has many years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the general public, villagers, five days per week. 

She has had two previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~$145 USD).  SPBD loans are Muliolo's only access to capital, because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will pay for her children's semester fee at school. She will also use her loan to purchase a frying pan, sack of sugar and sacks of flour and also some cooking oil.

loans.use: Purchase a frying pan, sacks of sugar and flour and cooking oil also for paying her children's semester fees.

loans.name: Mr. Ban Vebol's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Ten people in Chrolong Village in Kampong Chhnang Province have formed to request a village bank loan which will be used for various purposes. Mr. Ban V. is the village bank president and he is a fisherman in the local lake. In order to catch more fish, Mr. Ban V. has decided to request a loan to purchase more fish nets. His wife, Mrs. Eourn Im, owns a small store in the local village from which she sells desserts . Mr. Ban V. is 27 years old and the father of two young children who are both too young to work or study.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. The members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more fish nets

loans.name: Rasela

texts.en:
Rasela E., 54 and married with eight children, has many years of experience in the shop business. Operating the shop herself, but with the support of her children, she sells to the general public seven days per week; her weekly net cash flow is about $330.

Rasela is requesting a loan in order to buy more products for her shop. She has two previous loans from SPBD, her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase chicken, sausages, cooking oil, sugar, salt, flour, rice, onions

loans.name: Salafai

texts.en:
Salafai A. F., 52, is married with 3 children. She has 2 years of experience in the canteen business. She sells to the general public and villagers 5 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).

SPBD loans are Salafai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. A new member of the program running a canteen business, she wishes to supply all the children of their village school.

loans.use: Purchase frying pan, sack of sugar, sack of flour, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mrs. Out Saron's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is located in Tro Ngel Village in Kampong Chhnang Province and consists of ten people. They plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Uot S., a farmer, was selected by the members as the village bank to be president. She cultivates rice on a 5-hectar field. Her field is far from irrigation sources so it is very difficult for her to water her crop without a pump. Mrs. Uot S. is requesting a loan to purchase fuel for her pump that is used to water her crop. Her husband, Kung Sambean, helps her on the plantation. Mrs. Uot S. is 54 years old and the mother of two children who both help their parents on the plantation. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Eight members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fuel to operate her pump for watering her crop.

loans.name: Sofai

texts.en: Sofai T., 56, is married with 9 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the taro and banana plantation business. She sells to the general public, villagers 3 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (~291 USD).  SPBD loans are Sofai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She is the centre chief of their village, running a plantation with the support of her relatives.

loans.use: Purchase loan will be used for purchasing wheelbarow, spade, crowbar, weedkiller chemicals and fungicide for prevention of taro blight

loans.name: Zokirjon

texts.en: Zokirjon A. is 34 years old and lives in the Spitamen region of Tajikistan. He sells audio and video accessories in the central bazaar. He has 10 years of experience in this business. Zokirjon has the education of an electronic master. He is a very hard-working man so he has a good reputation and a many repeat customers. Zokirjon is asking for a loan of 3100 STJ ($925 USD) for four months to increase his inventory.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Run Oeurn's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Run O. is a village bank president of thirteen people who all live Korng Keb Village in the Kampong Chhnang Province. The loan will be used for different purposes. For instance, Mrs. Run O. is a pig breeder who is currently raising one pig. Since this business is going well, she would like to expand it so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy two more piglets for breeding. Mrs. Run O. is 34 years old and the mother of six children, four of whom are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Chem Kech, is a breeder who is raising six cows. Aside from this business, he owns a 2-hectar rice field. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Nine members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase two more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Vailaasia

texts.en: Vailaasia M., 30, is married with three children.  She has three years of experience in the food business, making pancakes. She sells to the general public in her village five days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD).  SPBD loans are Vailaasia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Vai is requesting a loan for the first time and wishes to start her own pancake business.

loans.use: Purchase sack of sugar, flour, cooking oil, yeast and frying pan.

loans.name: Javlon

texts.en: Mr. J. Javlon is 29 years old and lives in the Spitamen region. He is very polite and kind by nature. He works hard to ensure a good future for his 3 children.  Mr. Javlon received his first loan from MicroInvest in 2008 and has been a reliable client. He had no problems repaying the previous loan.  Now he wants to take another loan to develop his business. Mr. Javlon trades in the local bazaar, selling house slippers and waterproof shoe covers. Mr. J. Javlon requests a business development loan of 2100 STJ (USD $625) for 3 months, to import new goods and increase his business.  He thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To buy new goods for his business

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.en: A. Jamshed was born in 1986 in the Spitamen region. He is a master of TV and audio repair.  He has a repair shop where he works with his brother. He has worked in the present business for 4 years. In addition, he trades in spare parts and TV-audio accessories. Mr. A. Jamshed applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 3600 STJ (USD $1075) for 4 months to increase his work area. He thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To increase his work area

loans.name: Taulau

texts.en: Taulau T., 34, is married with seven children. She has many years of experience making pancakes. She sells to the general public & other villagers five days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD). SPBD loans are Taulau's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Taulau aims to start her own business to help her husband support their family

loans.use: Purchase sack of sugar, flour, cooking oil, yeast and frying pan

loans.name: Nurmamat

texts.en: M. Nurmamat was born in 1952 in the Spitamen region. He is married and has 4 children. He trades in the local bazaar. He buys goods from wholesale suppliers. He has repeat customers and a good assortment of items. Mr. M. Nurmamat first applied to MicroInvest in 2008. He is a reliable client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. He applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 2600 STJ (USD $775) for 3 months to import new goods. He thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To import new goods

loans.name: Sugran

texts.en:
Sugran baji is a wife of M. and lives in a small area named Yadgar in the city Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the last 22 years. She is the mother of six children: three sons and three daughters. Her elder daughter runs a beauty parlor. The next to her is in the 9th standard grade. Her younger daughter and her younger son are in the 5th standard grade. Her first two sons help their father in the making of lathe machines (machines that make tools).

Sugran baji's husband buys spare parts and makes lathe machines that he then sells in different cities of Pakistan (Karachi, Multan). He has been in this business for the last 30 years.

Sugran baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She has successfully repaid her 4 loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy spare parts to make another lathe machine to help her husband's business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to make a lathe machine

loans.name: Rafoat

texts.en: R. Rafoat was born in 1966 in the Spitamen region. She is divorced and has 2 children. She trades in the local bazaar and works with wholesale suppliers. She has repeat customers and a good assortment of items. She has been working in this business for 9 years. Mrs. R. Rafoat first applied to MicroInvest in 2008.  She is a reliable client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. She applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 2200 STJ (USD $650) for 4 months to import new goods. She thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To import new goods

loans.name: Faaopopo

texts.en: Faapopo S., 48, is married and has two children. She has many years of experience in the taro and banana plantation business. She sells her products two days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 540 Tala (about $225 USD).  She is asking for a $300 USD loan to buy equipment and supplies (such as a wheelbarrow, spade, crowbar, weedkiller chemicals, and focshek fungicide for prevention of taro blight) for her plantation. SPBD loans are Faapopo's only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Mrs. Norm Sokhann's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan which consists of nineteen people is located in Preark Roka Village in the Kandal Province. Mrs. Norn S. is the village bank president and was selected by the members. She is a garment factory worker who makes a small salary to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chhun Khom, is a construction worker who earns less than $2 per day. They live in poor conditions. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Norn S. is requesting a loan to buy a calf to start a breeding business. She is 33 years old and the mother of two children one of whom is attending the local school while the four year old stays home. 

Two members in this village loan have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a calf to start a breeding business.

loans.name: Ofa

texts.en: Ofa F., 29, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in a taro and banana plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers. SPBD loans are Ofa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks

loans.use: To purchase a wheelbarow, spade, crowbar, weedkiller chemicals and fungicide for prevention of taro blight

loans.name: Kamila

texts.en: Kamila K., 33, is married with 4 children. She has many years of experience in a food stall business. She sells to the general public and villagers 5 days per week. She has had 4 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Kamila's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to purchase a sack of cement, iron roofing and nails for building a proper shelter for her stall.

loans.use: To purchase chicken, potatoes, tomato sauce, rice, oil, gas oven, gas bottle, flour, salt etc.

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en: R. Nasiba is 35 years old and lives in the Spitamen region. She is married and has 4 children. She trades in the local bazaar and works with wholesale suppliers. She has repeat customers and a good assortment of items. She has worked in this business for 4 years. Mrs. R. Nasiba first applied to MicroInvest in 2008. She is a reliable client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. She applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 2600 STJ (USD $775) for 3 months to import new goods. She thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To import new goods

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem baji is a widow of M. and lives in a small area named Yadgar in the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 25 years. She is the mother of one son. Her son drives a 32-seater local vehicle. Her husband passed away in 1990.

Naseem baji is a very brave woman. She did not let herself be pulled down in the tragic time of her husband's death.

She started a business buying and selling different items such as clothes, dishwashing soaps and crockery. She has been in this profession for the last 18 years. She is applying for a loan to buy more items to resell for her business.

loans.use: To buy items to resell

loans.name: Auvasa

texts.en: Auvasa M. F., 70, is married and has seven children. She has many years of experience in the sewing business. She sells the products she makes five days a week. She has six previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (about $104 USD).  SPBD loans are Auvasa's only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She will use the loan to buy items for her sewing business (material, thread, elastic, and so forth) and to pay for her grandson's school fees.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Miriama

texts.en:
Miriama T., 49 and married with six children, has many years of experience in the banana plantation and shop businesses, selling to the general public six days per week. She has proven herself to be responsible borrower from previous loans with SPBD, and is now requesting a new loan to purchase chemicals, fertilizers, pesticide, and sacks of sugar, rice and flour.

SPBD loans are Miriama's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for loans from the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals, fertilizers, pesticide, sacks of sugar, rice and flour

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en: S. Saodat is 27 years old and lives in the Spitamen region. She is married and has 3 children. She trades in the local bazaar and works with wholesale suppliers. She has repeat customers and a good assortment of items. She has been working in this business for 5 years. Mrs. S. Saodat first applied to MicroInvest in 2008. She is a reliable client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. She applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 2800 STJ (USD $825) for 4 months to import new goods. She thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To import new goods

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en:
Rukhsana baji is a wife of M. and lives in a small area named Yadgar in the city Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the last 8 years. She is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son has a spare parts business. The next to him makes lathe machines (machines that make tools) and sells them in different cities of Pakistan. Her daughter is in the 6th standard grade.

Rukhsana baji's husband is a tailor by profession. He has been a tailor for seven years.

Rukhsana baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy spare parts that are used to make lathe machines. This will help to expand her younger son's business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to make lathe machines

loans.name: Tauese

texts.en: Tauese P., 48, is married with six children.  She has many years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers four days per week. She an established member of the program and has had six previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 560 Tala (~233 USD).  SPBD loans are Tauese's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She runs a plantation business. Her husband is unemployed but is helping out with the business.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer, weedkiller chemicals, gromozone, knives, rake, hose, pucket, axe, and gloves.

loans.name: Tafaoga

texts.en:
Tafaoga F., 26, is married with three children. She has many years of experience in the retail business. She sells to the general public and villagers seven days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 560 Tala (~233 USD).  

SPBD loans are Tafaoga's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She runs a very small shop in her community. With the first loan she borrowed, she was able to start up her business and she has successfully paid off this loan. 

She is now requesting her next loan to purchase a fridge and shelves for her shop.

loans.use: Purchase purcahse a fridge for drinks and shelving display cabinets

loans.name: Sefulu

texts.en:
Sefulu L., 67, is married with 8 children. She has many years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the villagers and general public 7 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Sefulu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She mainly supplies her village and sometimes the general public, people from nearby villages.

loans.use: Purchase kerosene cooker, frying pan, sack of flour, sack of sugar, cooking oil, baking powder, plastic bags and food cover

loans.name: Khurshida

texts.en: S. Khurshida lives in the Spitamen region and is 25 years old. She is married and has 2 children. She works in the local bazaar and trades in dry goods for making national dresses. She faces strong competition so she has to attract customers with a good assortment. She is polite and kind. Mrs. S. Khurshida applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 2600 STJ (USD $775) for 3 months to increase her trading area.

loans.use: To increase her trade area

loans.name: Luaono

texts.en: Luaono D., 39, is married with 3 children. She has many years of experience in a shop business. She sells to the villagers and general public 7 days per week. She has had 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1200 Tala (approximately 500 USD). SPBD loans are Luaono's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She is the only member in the family running her shop.

loans.use: To purchase tinned meats, frozen foods, candies, snacks, beverages, kitchen facilities, bathroom facilities and shelving display.

loans.name: Guzalhon

texts.en: S. Guzalhon lives in the Spitamen region and is 24 years old. She is married and has 2 children. She is a dressmaker. She works in the local bazaar and trades in dry goods for making national dresses. She faces strong competition so she has to attract customers with a good assortment. She is also a polite and kind woman. Mrs. S. Guzalhon applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 2600 STJ (USD $775) for 3 months to import new goods.

loans.use: To import new goods

loans.name: Leutu

texts.en: Leutu F., 41, is married with 2 children. She has many years of experience in a taro plantation business. She sells to the villagers 4 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 320 Tala (approximately 133 USD). SPBD loans are Leutu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband and children will do the farming.

loans.use: To purchase taro tubers, weed killer, pesticides, chemicals and a shovel

loans.name: Maletina

texts.en: Maletina I., 58, is married with 10 children. She has many years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to villagers and general public 7 days per week. She has had 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD). SPBD loans are Maletina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for renovating her house, to purchase timber, sacks of cement, and iron roofing. Her pancake business is very famous around her area due to her secret recipes.

loans.use: To purchase a frying pan, sack of sugar, sack of flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Ablonazar

texts.en: K. Ablonazar was born in the Spitamen region of Tajikistan. He is married and has 3 children. He is an economist, but livestock provides most of his income. Mr. K. Ablonazar has worked in the livestock business for his whole life, since he started helping his father to take care of their animals. Now he is engaged in livestock purchasing and selling. He has good business skills. Although he has a good group of livestock, he now wants to buy one more pedigree bull. Consequently, he is seeking a business development loan through KIVA in the amount of 2600 STJ (USD $775) over 3 months for that specific purpose.

loans.use: To buy one more pedigree bull

loans.name: Marufjon

texts.en: Y. Marufjon was born in 1989 in the Spitamen region. He is a master of TV and audio repairing and has his own repair shop. He has worked in the present business for 6 years; he started in this line of work by helping his father. In addition, he trades in spare parts and TV-audio accessories. Mr. Y. Marufjon applies to KIVA for a business development loan of 2800 STJ (USD $825) for 5 months, to buy new testing equipment. He thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To buy new equipment

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia baji is a wife of M. and lives in a small area named Yadgar in the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the last 22 years. She is the mother of six sons. Her elder son has a spare parts business. The next to him is a driver by profession. The others are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.

Razia baji's husband has a harvester machine. He has been working with this machine for the last 5 years.

Razia baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to repair her husband's harvester machine.

Note: The harvester machine is showed in this picture. Razia baji is holding the pictures of the machine.

loans.use: To repair a harvester machine

loans.name: Mrs. Nheom Sorn's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Seventeen people in Preark Roka Village in Kandal Province are applying for a village bank loan. 

Mrs. Nheom S. was selected by the members to be the village bank president. She owns 1.5 hectares of land (~3.7 acres), on which she grows rice to earn her living. Her husband, Mr. Kung Roem, is a construction worker who makes less than $2 to support his family. Mrs. Nheom S. is 53 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory; the remaining two attend the local school. Although Mrs. Nheom S.'s family members have different businesses, they still live in an old house and in poor conditions. In order to improve her standard of living, Mrs. Nheom S. decided to ask for a loan. She will use the money, along with her savings to build a new house for her family. 

Mr. Prum V. did not come to the meeting, so he is represented by his wife, who appears in the photo. Mrs. Ky Navy is the group guarantor. She is also shown in the picture. 

This is a village bank loan which is paid in full at the end of its term. Eight of members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly-payment loans. Members with end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. 

End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Magezi Buggaga Lending Group

texts.en:
S. Lawrence is a married man with two children; he also cares for one orphaned child. All of the children attend the same primary school.
