Juanita V. trabaja de secretaria con un Licenciado, su esposo en una maquiladora de la ciudad y también su hijo que vive con ella trabaja  en una guarecería de asistente para ayudarla en sus gastos con estos ingresos pagaran el préstamo otorgado.
texts.en:
Juanita V. Ramirez has children who are at the age where they need their own room for their privacy. She will first use the loan for the construction of one room in the back of where she lives, and if they finish that project with money left over they will start the construction of another room on top of their home. The home is subsidized by the organization INFONAVIT, which part of a government program, and Juanita has come to our organization in order to get help to increase her families standard of living with a loan of $600 dollars. Juanita V. works as a secretary for a Lawyer, and her husband works in a factory in the city. Her son that lives with her also works as an assistant in a shelter in order to help out with expenses, and with all of these incomes they will be able to pay back the loan.

Translated from Spanish by James Lombardo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a new room

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es:
José Luís P. Q.  vive en una casa de madera por lo que se ve en la necesidad arreglar el techo  ya que es de lamina y en tiempote frió es muy helado también cuando llueve se le traspasa el agua, ya vienen estas temporadas y el quiere arreglar este problema lo antes posible. Como pueden ver es una persona muy humilde que necesita de nuestra ayuda el tiene hijos y no desea se que pudieran enfermarse. José Luis solo necesita la cantidad de $150 dólares.
El y su esposa trabajan en una maquiladora de la ciudad pero lo que ganan es muy poco para poder hacerlo de contado pero si en pagos muy pequeños y largo plazo.
texts.en:
José Luís P. Q. lives in a wooden house for which he sees the need to fix the roof since it is made of laminate and, in cold weather, becomes very frozen. Also, when it rains, water seeps through. These seasons are approaching and he wishes to fix this problem as soon as possible. As you may be able to see, he is a humble person who needs our help. He has children and he does not want them to become ill. José Luís needs only $150. He and his wife work in a factory in the city, however they earn very little and to be able to make what they need would take a long time and be in small payments.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fix the roof of his house.

loans.name: Thik's Group

texts.en:
Thik H., 38, is married to Sophal CH., 33, and have two children who are currently in school. Sophal is a Khmer style house builder and his income is not steady, so he helps his wife in his spare time. Thik has been selling fruit since 1996 at the market. Thik lacks the capital to purchase more fruit to sell. She has requested a loan of US$400 to purchase more fruit stock. Thik is the leader of a small group of three members, who all live in the Norea Commune, Battambang Province, and have requested the following loans:

1. Sareing R., 47, widowed, who is a vegetable and fruit seller. She requests a loan of US$250 to to help serve her business operation.

2. Lim M., 64, is fruit seller. Lim seeks a loan of US$200 to stock fruits in order to resell.

3. Saraim M., 49, widowed, is dessert seller. Saraim requests a loan of US$200 to purchase more dessert ingredients.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit stocks

loans.name: Pong

texts.en: Pong P. is 29, and is married with three children who all attend school. They live in Leangdaiy Commune, in the Siem Reap Province. Pong's wife is a dessert seller in the village. Pong drives a motorcycle taxi with a trailer everyday to transport passengers and goods. Because his trailer is old, Pong seeks a loan of US$350 to replace his old one. The loan will be expanding his daily revenue and daily output.

loans.use: to change his trailer to replace his old one

loans.name: Dianes

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 52-year-old Daines from Dar es Salaam, a divorced woman with three children between the ages of 25 and 31 years. Daines has been operating a bar business since 2003. Her bar is a good place to relax with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. You can relax on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting 'mishikaki' (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to everyone who happens to wander by.

Daines 's business is doing well as she works 16 hours per day, seven days per week, assisted by three employees. She currently earns about $100 monthly and is requesting a loan of $250 in order to buy additional stocks of beer and soda. In the future, she plans to purchase more equipment including tables, chairs and glasses. Daines thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase soda and beer in bulk for her bar.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is Esther from Dar es Salaam, married with three children between the ages of 9 and 17. Since 2007, Esther has been operating a shop that sells traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women called kanga and vitenge. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric, often with a border along all four sides, printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people.

Esther's business is doing well as she works 12 hours per day, six days per week, earning about $100 monthly from her business. She is requesting a loan of $250 in order to buy more African traditional cloth such as kanga and vitenge. In the future, she plans to increase the stock of African traditional cloths for her shop. Esther thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase traditional African cloth in bulk.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 22-year-old Lydia from Dar es Salaam; she is single. Lydia has been running a café since 2007. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all-local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. Lydia's business is doing well. She works at the business for four hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee. Lydia currently earns about 300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to purchase additional cooking oil, wheat flour, rice and maize flour. In the future, she plans to establish open a second location for her business. Lydia thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cooking ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Modesta from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children between the ages of 12 and 28; she has also taken in two dependent orphans. Modesta has been running a nursery school since 2008, where she takes care of young boys and girls and prepares them for elementary school. Modesta's business is doing well. She works at the business for six hours per day, five days a week and is assisted by three employees. Modesta currently earns about 500 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to buy school equipment such as books, desks, and chalk. In the future, she plans to establish a poultry business in addition. Modesta thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy books and other supplies for her nursery school

loans.name: Valeria

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Valeria from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children between the ages of 7 and 11. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting three dependents who are orphans. Valeria has been running a business selling traditional Arican cloth called kanga and vitenge. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric, often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile--the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people. Valeria works at the business for 13 hours per day, seven days a week. Valeria currently earns about 200 USD from her business, and she is requesting a loan of 250 USD to buy additional traditional African cloths. In the future, she plans to increase the amount of commodities in her business. Valeria thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase traditional African cloth in bulk

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 37-year -ld Rosemary from Dar es Salaam. She is married with one child who is 16 years old. Rosemary has been running a tailoring business since 2005, and her business is doing well. She works at the business for 12 hours per day and seven days per week. Rosemary currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to purchase additional cloth which she uses for making dresses, bedsheets and other items. In the future, she plans to expand her business by adding more sewing machines. Rosemary thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional cloth for her tailoring business

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 37-year-old Salma from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children between the ages of two and 13 years. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent because her parents do not take care of her. Salma has been running a stationary business since 2007. Stationary sales is a business in which micro-entrepreneurs demonstrate their business savvy, with most sellers placing their shops, stalls, or tables strategically close to post offices, banks, schools and universities. Her business is doing well. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, five days per week and is assisted by one employee. Salma currently earns about 300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to purchase more stationary supplies. In the future, she plans to expand her stationary business by adding books, rulers, as well a photocopy machine. Salma thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

Liliani has been running a charcoal business since 2004. Charcoal is the kind of fuel used for cooking food in Tanzania. Woods are burned under limited air to produce charcoal. Liliani is normally buying charcoal from those who produce it, then she sells it to customers around her area. Her business is doing well. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by two employees. Liliani currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500 USD in order to purchase additional stock of charcoal. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Liliani thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Pelagia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Pelagia L. from Dar es Salaam. She is divorced with one child five years old. Pelagia has been running a poultry business since 2005. Raising kuku or poultry is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. First, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Second, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Third, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. Her business is doing well. She works at the business for four hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee. Pelagia currently earns about 300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 850 USD in order to purchase more chicks. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Pelagia thanks you for your support!

In the future, she plans to expands her business. Juliana thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Lulu

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is Lulu S. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children, between the ages of four and twenty-six. She is also responsible for supporting two dependent orphans.

Lulu has been running a café since 2007. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table, and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. Lulu's business is doing well. She works for eight hours per day, seven days a week and currently earns about $150. She is requesting a loan of $250 to renovate café building and to purchase additional cooking oil, wheat flour, and maize flour. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Lulu thanks you for your support!

This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cooking supplies for her cafe.

Asha currently earns about $300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $850 USD to buy more fish for her business. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Asha thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Pascazia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 29 year old Pascazia M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children, age of two and four.

Pascazia has been running a genge, or grocery store, since 2007. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof that sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It's the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don't have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

Pascazia's business is doing well. She works at the business for 16 hours a day, six days per week, and is assisted by three employees. She currently earns about $300 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $850 to purchase inventory in bulk for her store. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Pascazia thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Atuganile

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Atuganile M. from Dar es Salaam She is single and has two children, ages 13 and 18. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting three other dependants because their parents do not take care of them. Atuganile has been running a mobile phone accessories business since 2004. It is amazing how many people have mobile phones in Tanzania. This is probably attributable to the fact that it is the only form of phone communication available to most people, because there are few landlines. Also, mobile phones are relatively cheap in Tanzania. Her business is doing well. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 per week and is assisted by two employees. Atuganile currently earns about $100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $750 USD to purchase additional mobile phone accessories. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Atuganile thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Justo

texts.es:
Hola mi nombre es Justo H. tengo 42 años de edad, resido en la Colonia Villanueva de la Ciudad Capital, estoy casado y laboro como guardia de seguridad, desde hace varios meses estoy planeando arreglar el techo de mi casa ya que en estos dias de muchas lluvias se me mete el agua adentro de mi casa y eso es un problema muy grave ya que se me mojan varias cosas, mi esposa es ama de casa, con los ingresos que tengo de mi trabajo me alcanza para cubrir con los gastos de mi hogar y para cubrir con otras necesidades, gracias a ello hemos salido adelante con mi esposa.
soy una persona luchadora que cumplo a cabalidad con mis compromisos.
texts.en:
Hello. My name is Justo H., I’m 42 years old, I live in the Villanueva neighborhood of Capital city. I’m married and I work as a security guard. For a few months I have been planning to fix the roof of my house as currently rain enters my home and this is a serious problem as many of my things get wet. My wife is a housewife. With the income I have from my job I cover my household expenses and other necessities. Thankfully my wife and I have been able to get ahead. I am a person who capably fights to meet my obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials to renovate the roof of his home

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 33 year old Tatu M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children, between the ages of one and fifteen. She is also responsible for supporting one dependent child whose parents do not take care of her.

Tatu has been running a charcoal business since 2007. Charcoal is a type of fuel that is used locally to prepare food and boil water. Tatu's business is doing well. She works at it for twelve hours per day, six days per week, and currently earns about $100 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $675 to purchase additional stock of charcoal. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Tatu thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Gavino Marcelino

texts.es: El Sr. Gavino habita en un barrio de la capital de Managua que se llama Laureles Norte, tiene 48 años de edad, soltero,  su negocio es diseñador modista desde hace diez años que comenzó con dinero propio pues desde muy joven le ha gustado poner en practicas partes de sus sueños. Con la solicitud de préstamo es para comprar materia prima como: tela accesorios de costura para fortalecer su negocio con todos los productos para hacer sus vestidos. A futuro es poder tener una infraestructura grande donde pueda tener muchas maquinas y personas trabajando, en su diseños y poder exportar sus estilos y variedad.
texts.en:
Mr. Gavino lives in the Laureles Norte neighborhood of the capital city, Managua. He is 48 years old, single, and he has been a fashion designer for 10 years. He began his business with his own money. Since he was a young man he has liked making his dreams reality. He is asking for a loan to buy raw material such as fabric and sewing accessories to strengthen his business as he makes dresses. In the future he wants to be able to have a large infrastructure where he can have many machines and people working on his designs and be able to export his styles and variety of clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric and sewing accessories

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia T. N. is 51 years old. She is married and the mother of two children. Felicia is very resourceful when it comes to providing for her family. She is a food vendor who sells cooked yam and stew as well plastic bowls. She sells yam in the mornings and switch over to the sale of plastic bowls in the afternoon. Yam is peeled and cooked and is eaten with hot pepper and fried fish or gravy stew. She has many customers since many Ghanaian enjoy cooked yam for breakfast, lunch, and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like tubers of yam, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children's education. She belongs to the community group called The Good Shepherd Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of loans for each other.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 45 years old, married, and has three children.  He is a member of the community group "Adjinyemise" (translation: do not betray your brother). Members guarantee each other to provide social collateral to access loans and to provide peer support.

Moses W. is a petty trader. He sells bags of maize at the community market of Koforidua in Ghana. He treks to farming communities to buy from farmers in order to sell retail to his customers. He wants to use the loan to buy more maize to serve his customers. He dreams of expanding his business to include additional produce such as plantains, yams and cassava to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex T., a 43-year-old businessman, is married with two children who are currently in school. He belongs to the community group called Adjinyemise Trust Group, whose members support one another both in accessing and repaying loans. He started trading in live animals such as goats and sheep seven years ago, and he enjoys the business. Alex believes in hard work and dedication, trekking to the northern part of Ghana to purchase the animals and retailing them to local restaurant operators. With extensive marketing experience, he is one of the most successful traders in Koforidua market.

Alex is requesting a loan to buy more goats and sheep in order to supply his customers with even more animals. He hopes to thereby raise his income and his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy more live animals such as goats and sheep.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen A. D. is a 45 year old man. He is married and has two children who are currently in school.  He belongs to the community group named Adjinyemise Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee each other as social collateral to access loans and provide peer support. Stephen is in the photo which was taken during a group meeting. 

He is a fisherman who fishes in the Kpong River in the Volta region of Ghana. Many traders purchase his fish because it is fresh and affordable. With the loan, Stephen wants to purchase a fishing net and repair his fishing canon. For sometime now, Stephen's canon has been giving him problems. He hopes that the loan will help him meet the demand and also provide him with enough income to sponsor his childrens' education. He appreciates the assistance.

loans.use: to buy a fishing net and repair his fishing canon

loans.name: Tetteh

texts.en:
Tetteh K. is a 30 year old trader who is married and has two kids.  His children are currently in school.  His major challenge is paying school fees.  He hopes to increase his savings to support his childrens' education to give them better future career opportunities. He belongs to the community group called "Adjinyemise" Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other as social collateral and assist one another in repaying their loans.

He has been selling cereal and charcoal in the local market for three years now. He requests a loan to enable him to trek to surrounding villages to buy more stock of maize and charcoal in order to avoid middlemen.  This will allow him to grow his business and increase profit.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize and charcoal.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 46 years old, married, and has two children who are in school. He is  a very hard working and resourceful father. He belongs to the community group called "Adjinyemise" (translation: do not betray your brother) Trust Group.  In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans.

He is a retailer of charcoal in his neighborhood. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all traditional Ghanaian homes.  Joseph obtains his supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Koforidua and sells it retail to his customers. He will use the loan to buy bulk supplies of charcoal. He hopes to increase savings so he can pay his childrens' educational fees.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To start a small business selling clothing, beauty products and other goods.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To start selling clothing and beauty products.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel B. is a 54 year old businessman. He is a husband and father of four children, who are currently in school.  He belongs to the community group named 'Adjinyemise' Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another in repaying their loans. 

He sells goats and sheep. He buys the goats and the sheep from the northern part of the country and supplies them to restaurant operators. Goat meat is enjoyed by many Ghanaians because of the good flavor and affordability. His business has been slow to grow because of inadequate funds to buy the animals. With the loan, he wants to buy in bulk. He believes the loan will allow him to meet the demands of his customers. He also hopes to save more money to provide for his children.

loans.use: To buy goats and sheep in bulk.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina is a wife and the mother of four children, who are now independent.  She is a member of the group named 'Adjinyemise' Trust Group.  Members in this group guarantee and provide support to one another in repaying their loans. 

Faustina Akwertey has been selling used clothes for the past year at the Odumase market in Koforidua, Ghana. She relies on the income from her sales to support her household, both in the provision of food and payment of utility bills.  She is requesting a loan to enable her to inject more capital into her business.  She will purchase more bales of used clothes.  She hopes to reinvest her income into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more lace and used clothes.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha T. is a 39 year old divorced woman. She is the mother of four school going children.  She is a member of the group called 'Adjinyemise' Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee and provide support to one another in repaying their loans. Her picture was taking after her group meeting.  

In the past year she decided to learn a trade to earn a living. She now runs a stand selling cloth and slippers. She has insufficient working capital to run the business.  A loan will allow her to inject more working capital into the business and scale up the operation.  The funds would be used to upgrade her inventory by purchasing bulk amounts of good quality merchandise. She believes that the subsequent earnings will enable her to pay for the childrens' school fees  She is grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To purchase clothand slippers.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher N. is thirty years old. He is single and loves work. He has been spray-painting cars for the past three years. He also does car welding when the need arises. He owns a car spray-painting shop, where customers bring their cars to paint. He also paints rusted durable goods, such as refrigerators, stove, and microwaves. 

He is requesting a loan to buy additional tools and materials, such as assorted paints, sand paper, and spraying machines, to expand his operations. 

He belongs to the "Action Faith Trust" community group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and peer pressure to repay the loan. His picture was taken at his business site.

loans.use: To buy additional tools and materials for his painting business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca Teye P. is 30 years old. She is married and the mother of two children. At the moment, one of her children attends school.  She is a member of a group named Action Faith Trust Group.  In this group, members guarantee and assist one another in repaying their loans. Her picture was taken during their group meeting. 

She sells baby clothes, pampers, powder, napkins, detergent, feeding bottles and other items through hawking. She balances the items on her head and walks miles to her customers. She needs a loan to enable her to inject more capital into her business. The loan will pay for more supplies and materials to increase her stock.  The profits will be used to provide her children with a good education.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of baby clothes, napkins, pampers, baby oil, detergent and plastic materials.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose O. is a 28 year old single woman with one child who is currently in school. She is a very supportive mother. 
She is a member of a community group named Action Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another in repaying their loans.

Rose has operated a seamstress shop for the past seven years. She trains two young ladies in sewing to equip them with skills and experience for their future careers. She sews womens' clothing in various styles such as kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes etc. She will use the loan to buy more sewing materials including linen, thread, and thimbles to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children in school.

loans.use: To buy more sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George K. is the father of one child who is currently in school.  He belongs to the community group named King David Trust Group. In this group, members agree to guarantee each other as social collateral to order to access loans. 

George is a 32 year old businessman. He is a supplier and distributor of cement in his community. He has been in this business for the past year. There is a constant demand for cement since it is necessary for building.  He is requesting a loan to buy a truck so he can deliver large quantities of cement to his customers.  He also needs the loan to re-stock his shop and improve sales.  The loan will allow him to grow his business.

loans.use: To buy increased stock of cement.

loans.name: Dautey

texts.en:
Dautey is a 39-year-old trader who is married and has three children. She believes in hard work and dedication as the primary antidote to poverty. She is very serious about her business. She trades in maize and charcoal. She has been trading for the past five years and has been an important resource to her family. 

Dautey wants to use this loan to buy larger supplies of maize and charcoal to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of the increasing prices that result from the current food crisis in the country. 

She is a member of the King David trust group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral and provide support for themselves to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy larger supplies of maize and charcoal.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther A. is 32 years old, married, and the mother of one child. Her child is currently in school. To support her child, she has been operating a hair dressing salon and selling maize in the neighborhood. She says that selling maize is very lucrative.  Therefore, she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to earn a good income to sponsor her childs' education. Esther is a member of a group named Action Faith.  Members agree to guarantee each other as social collateral in repaying their loans.

loans.use: To buy more stock of maize, hair creams etc.

loans.name: Abraham

texts.en:
Abraham T., 32 years old and married with two children currently in school, trades in maize and pepper in the local market of Odumase, a town in the Eastern region of Ghana. He belongs to the community group called King David Trust Group, whose members support one another in their quest for and repayment of loans.

Scarcity of funds to support the business is a problem, so he is requesting a loan to enable him to buy more bags of maize in bulk to grow his business and increase sales. He hopes to increase his savings to support the children's education to give them better future career opportunities.

loans.use: To buy an increased stock of maize and pepper.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph T. is a 36 year old father of one child.  His child is currently in school. He is very hard working and resourceful. He owns a taxi and also sells in charcoal in his neighborhood. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy used for cooking in most Ghanaian traditional homes. Joseph obtains his supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Koforidua, which is also where he lives and sells to his customers. He wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of charcoal to increase his inventory. He hopes the loan will enable him to increase his savings to pay for his childs' educational fees. 

He belongs to a community group named King David Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for each another as social collateral in accessing and repaying loans. The photograph is from their group meeting.

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of charcoal.
